column4: Im installing fedora with  windows and ubuntu, and the windows partition is taking up all the free space. I have tons of freespace on the windows partition, so if i shrhink the windows partition, will it automatically make a new partition with the free space?
Anyone can just answer this real quick?

Im installing fedora with  windows and ubuntu, and the windows partition is taking up all the free space. I have tons of freespace on the windows partition, so if i shrhink the windows partition, will it automatically make a new partition with the free space?
will shrinking a partition automatically get rid of the free space?
Will it automatically get rid of the free space in the partition?
-.- i know someone here could just say yes or no

Im installing fedora with  windows and ubuntu, and the windows partition is taking up all the free space. I have tons of freespace on the windows partition, so if i shrhink the windows partition, will it automatically make a new partition with the free space?
or will it take up data for the partition
No.  You have to resize another partition to claim that space or make a new one
Always back up your important stuff before playing with partitions
i dont have anything to back it up on
If you're really worried about it, there are freeware partition shrinkers that work in windows.
BTW, you are aware that this is an ubuntu support forum, right?
It's up to you, but leave a few gig of free space for Windows
It depends on the installer.  If it doesn't autodetect them, you can still add them manually.
You'd have to know where they boot from.  However, that sort of question would be better asked in a Fedora forum, as it is the fedora installer that would be doing the work.
